snippet: Once a believer in the offensive against the Taliban, Abdul Samad, who lost 11 family members in a rampage, is now insistent that United States forces get out. Officials said the attack was carried out by an American sergeant.
abstract: Afghan Abdul Samad, whose 11 family members were killed in rampage by United States staff sergeant, was once a believer in the offensive against the Taliban, but is now insistent that United States forces leave Afghanistan; incident has further tarnished Afghan-US relations, leaving many Afghans doubtful of the military's assertion that attack was the work of a single gunman.

byline.original: By TAIMOOR SHAH and GRAHAM BOWLEY
byline.contributor: Taimoor Shah reported from Panjwai, and Graham Bowley from Kabul, Afghanistan. Matthew Rosenberg and Sangar Rahimi contributed reporting from Kabul, and Elisabeth Bumiller en route to Kyrgyzstan.

lead_paragraph: Once a believer in the offensive against the Taliban, Abdul Samad, who lost 11 family members in a rampage, is now insistent that United States forces get out. Officials said the attack was carried out by an American sergeant.
